text.headline:
Christianity, Capitalism and White Supremacy - A Timeline
1455 - 2023
text.text: Documenting the history of White Supremacy and it's ties to Christianity and Capitalism.

text.headline: Romanus Pontifex of 1455
text.text: This papal bull legally granted Portugal the right to enslave any and all people they encounter south of Cape Bojador, on the coast of Western Sahara.

text.headline: First Africans in Virginia
text.text: A group of twenty and odd captive enslaved persons originally from modern-day Angola landed at Old Point Comfort in Hampton, Virginia in late August 1619.

media.caption: Resettlement of formerly enslaved people to Haiti

text.headline: The Haiti Experiment
text.text: On the night of December 31, 1862, a day before he issued the final Emancipation Proclamation to effectively end slavery in America, President Abraham Lincoln signed a contract with Bernard Kock, an entrepreneur and Florida cotton planter. Their agreement: to use federal funds to relocate 5,000 formerly enslaved people from the United States to Île à Vache ('Cow Island'), a small, 20-square-mile island off the southwestern coast of Haiti.

text.headline: Emancipation Procalamation
text.text: This was a presidential proclamation and executive order issued by United States President Abraham Lincoln, during the Civil War. The Proclamation changed the legal status of more than 3.5 million enslaved African Americans in the secessionist Confederate states from enslaved to free.

text.headline: Henry Truman
text.text: Henry Truman, a Black man, was shot and killed by Philadelphia Officer John Whiteside after being accused of shoplifting from a grocery store.

text.headline: Julie Hayden
text.text: Julia Hayden, was an American seventeen-year-old Black school teacher murdered by members of the White Man's League within days of starting a teaching position at a school for Black children in Tennessee.

media.caption: Racial conflict in Forsyth County, Georgia

text.headline: Racial conflict in Forsyth County, Georgia
text.text: Bands of white men, known as Night Riders from Cherokee and other nearby counties threatened and intimidated Black inhabitants. These families either fled or were killed and their properties were stolen from them. Those that left, fled to Hall and Gwinnett Counties. Within the next four months, an estimated 98% of the blacks living in the county had left due to Night Rider threats, or were murdered.

text.headline: Tulsa Race Massacre
text.text: The Tulsa race aassacre is considered one the worst incidents of racial violence in American history. Mobs of white residents burned and destroyed more than 35 square blocks of the neighborhood—at the time one of the wealthiest Black communities in the United States, colloquially known as Black Wall Street.

media.caption: Lynching of Thomas Shipp and Abram Smith

text.headline: Lynching of Thomas Shipp and Abram Smith
text.text: J. Thomas Shipp and Abraham S. Smith were young African-American men who were murdered in a spectacle lynching by a mob of thousands on August 7, 1930, in Marion, Indiana.

text.headline: January 6 United States Capitol Attack
text.text: Called to action by Trump, thousands of his supporters gathered in Washington, D.C., on January 5 and 6 to support his false claim that the 2020 election had been stolen by emboldened radical-left Democrats and to demand that Vice President Mike Pence and the Congress reject Biden's victory.
